title: Tuesday, 26th March 2019

Don't bother doing contracts with Goldman Sachs, they won't do much for bottom line, says Goldman Sachs analyst. Sort of.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Apple
nannounced a new credit card (“Apple Card”) which offers 3%/2%/1% cash back on purchases made directly-with-Apple/with-Apple-Pay/other-purchases. Even though Apple Pay is becoming more available we would still expect a large percentage of transactions to be done at the 1% return level (using the physical card) so we would expect the typical consumer to perceive the cash return rate to be OK but not great (vs. 1.5% on all transactions available on some competitor cards). Assuming a 35bp/dollar spent take rate (inline with a 20bps-50bps range based on industry checks), $1,000/user/month spend (roughly inline with Amex cards) and 21m users (~10% of iPhone installed base in the US), we estimate Apple Card could generate $882m in revenue and $0.12 in EPS (we show sensitivities in Exhibit 1 below). This would equate to just under a 1% uplift to CY20 FactSet consensus EPS.

JP11:15am

Of course, there was this moment from the event:

11:17 am
JP11:17am

Here's Richard Windsor of Radio Free Mobile blog fame:

JP11:18am

Apple has recognised that it needs to work on its Digital Life services and in that regard, today’s announcement represent some progress.
However, it remains very far short of offering anything like the quality of services that Google offers in Search or Maps, Facebook in Social Networking and Instant Messaging or Tencent in Gaming and Instant Messaging.
Consequently, these services are going to incrementally increase brand loyalty to the Apple Ecosystem and make a tiny financial contribution to the company.
It is important to remember that Apple needs 2.1bn subscribers paying $9.99 a month to make it a services company (see here) meaning that far more than this is required to move the needle.
Apple is hooked on hardware and there is very little bar a complete catastrophe that destroys its hardware business that is likely to change that.
It is on this basis that the company should be valued and there its valuation looks fair.
The value argument has now departed following its rally in Q1 2019, but as a hiding place from other concerns swirling around Facebook or Tencent, it still holds water.

JP11:18am

http://radiofreemo...ices-the-big-blue/

[We] calculate that its earnings contribution is likely to be immaterial vs CY20 EPS consensus. In our preview note heading into the event, we estimated that Apple News+ could contribute $306m/$0.05 in incremental subscription revenue/EPS which equates to an 0.4% uplift to CY20 consensus EPS.

Here's the argument. It's cash.

BE11:23am

Attractive returns in our bull, base and bear scenarios. We forecast rising FCF and +7% sustainable sector dividend yield in our base case and in our bear scenario, despite contrarian forecasts for falls in southern England new house prices. Our bear scenario forecast of a fall of 7.5-10% in 2019e in southern England new house prices was our base case previously in our initiation of coverage report, UK Housebuilders: 4-12% dividends despite downturn, 16 November 2018. In our bull scenario, we use the consensus assumption of flat UK house prices and implies substantial upside.

11:23 am
BE11:24am

New housing market share gains. We now see a lighter than we initially expected correction in southern England in 2019 for new house prices at 2.5-5%, based on recent evidence of a shift to house ownership from renting for 35-44 year olds, which is also evident in housebuilders’ resilient sales rates, despite the Brexit consumer gloom. We expect sustained low mortgage rates and the government Help-To-Buy equity loan scheme to maintain the market share gains of new homes.

red apple card v much to me looks like a test before a proper roll out. or not.
BE11:24am

Cash flow support. Despite raising our 2020e EBIT for the 10 housebuilders we cover by an average of 37%; on average they are 20% lower in our base case than the 2018a outturns and 18% below consensus. Nevertheless, FCF rises on average 34% in 2019-20 as we forecast shorter land banks in some cases and replenishment in southern England at lower prices, in a land market where the balance of power has shifted to the listed housebuilders as a result of planning reform and consolidation.

red if u need scale, u dont use gs
BE11:24am

Valuation upside. Our trend ROIC forecasts generally at around 20% are double our cost of capital estimates, generate trend average EV/IC multiple of nearly 2x, providing valuation upside vs sector average around 1.5x through 2022. We upgrade Persimmon (TP 2,960p from 2,480p) and Bovis Homes (TP1,350p from 1,060p) to Buy from Hold.

Peel Hunt:

11:30 am
JP11:30am

ur five questions answered (here): (1) The reduced consumer exposure due to the M&S deal, and higher service quality from “Andover” v2, once built, mitigate the longer term. (2) The M&S deal is more favourable than a Solutions deal in our view, and the previously unsigned deal from Coles, announced today, removed that risk. (3) Kroger is still excited and Sobey’s is excited and not expecting any impact to the design/timing of ‘game-changing’, ‘best-in-class killer technology’. (4) Ocado has different teams focusing on maintenance and innovation and the Andover’s rebuild will be more innovative and cutting edge. (5) Investigation is still on-going, however, the initial assessment shows it is very unlikely to be due the intrinsic design of the automated, robotic warehouse.

BE11:30am

Peel Hunt's been preaching the Ocado as pure-play tech thing for a time. And to be fair, they've been directionally correct.

JP11:30am

Today’s deal with Coles in Australia. Coles is one of Australia's largest retailers with 818 supermarkets, 911 liquor stores, and 712 Coles Express petrol stations, with sales in FY18 of AU$39.4bn (£22bn). This deal is slightly different, only in the sense that Coles is already an online market leader in the country, with AU$1bn+ of sales on an annualised basis. Coles will have two warehouses, one in Sydney and one in Melbourne and are expected to go-live within four years. Coles store pick operation will also migrate to Ocado in parallel. As ever, this deal is exclusive in country, subject to certain KPIs being met.

nightingale20201 Peel Hunt downgraded to a Hold after Andover's fire with TP at £10 (from £17)
11:30 am
JP11:31am

Transformational deal with M&S. The £750m cash injection and halving of exposure to the UK consumer is the best outcome for Ocado. It will accelerate CFC migrations/builds, fulfil more deals, and provide M&A optionality. On the face of it, this deal valued Ocado.com at £1.5bn (0.9x sales). However, we believe it is worth a lot more than that given: (1) 12.3 million M&S customers shop online for food not with Ocado; (2) 53% of the UK rank M&S’s food as the best quality; and (3) M&S’s ‘eat now’ can boost Ocado Zoom.

Bonnemort There are a lot of fake building certificate cards around....
JP11:31am

Goldman must have a take Bryce? Given the ex-vampire squid providence of the founders.

BE11:31am

They do, but it's quite dull.

rw42 Picking up keys to new flat next weds, i'm sure i'll have some steam to let off shortly afterwards!
11:31 am
BE11:32am

The better one I read was SocGen.

Grouchmonkey @BE you sold Ocado early on? That's nothing, I sold Fevertree.
BE11:32am

Which does the, "yes, this is all very nice but what about actual cash and stuff?" routine.

BE11:32am

The key question: what is priced in already by the market? We have no difficulty acknowledging that Ocado’s technology is very efficient and that for the last 18 months, the group has been doing a good job and demonstrating its ability to strike international partnerships. From a valuation standpoint, we value each international CFC at c.15p per share on the basis of favourable assumptions, i.e. a 5% fee on capacity and 100% capacity in year 3. At current share price levels, we calculate that the ‘market’ is factoring in c.30 additional CFCs over and above the 25 already contracted for. So fundamentally we think the stock is significantly overvalued following a c.60% jump since the start of the year. Bear in mind that the group’s recent deal with M&S did not have a surprisingly positive impact on the value of Ocado’s UK Retail business.
All eyes on execution Ocado looks set to be very busy for the next three/four years with 25 CFCs to build all around the world. Execution will be key, in particular as it could have an impact on the group’s ability to seal more long-term deals. All in all, we reiterate our Sell rating mainly on valuation grounds.

Grouchmonkey Sorry that was @JP not @BE. BE wd never do such a thing.
wayneJ Is there an opportunity to live in a Goldman Sachs Ecosystem? Buy Apple phone - get Apple Credit card - eat via Ocado (ex-GS) / M&S - live in a house owned by GS - spend your time in court due to a foreclosure activated by GS?
nightingale20201 Surely we would see some brokers upgrade on OCDO in the near term
11:33 am
JP11:33am

I mean, it's been painful for those of us who've been cynical about Ocado's reinvention.

BE11:34am

11:34 am

BE11:35am

BE11:35am

wayneJ I have not seen an engineer analyst do a proper competitive analysis on Ocado's technology. There are a lot of gushing retail analyst reports but to me it seems that there is a gaping hole in terms of true competitive analysis and looking at the moat.
11:35 am
BE11:35am

Have Barclays just to finish us on the theme.

BE11:35am

Entering any new market must be incremental good news for Ocado, but we think that Australia was one of the most likely new markets given its geography (a small number of large urban centres), a wealthy customer base and a concentrated retail industry. In this sense, doing a deal in Australia does not expand Ocado’s Total Addressable Market in the same way that announcing a deal in a more obscure location might do. We also find it interesting that it will take up to four years to open these two CFCs – compared with a timescale of more like two years for its first international deals (Casino, Sobeys). This may be a reflection of the increasingly long “to do” list that Ocado is building up. If indeed it does reflect a degree of capacity constraint then it may mean that the rapid pace of announcements seen in 1H18 will not continue. (Indeed, it has been almost a year since the last international deal – Kroger and Ocado signed their deal in May 2018.) Overall we see this as good news but at current share price levels we think the valuation of Ocado already assumes a steady flow of transactions like this.

MassimoJ @wayneJ - we can save with them now too via friendly old absolutely not squid like Marcus.

The outlook is where the problem lies, because there's a definite tone of management wanting to take the .... oh god, I can't say fizz here can I? .... out of expectations.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Here's RBC.

BE11:41am

We had already received Fever-Tree’s preliminary FY18 top-line results of £237m revenues (39% growth which has been upgraded to 40%). FY18 earnings were in line
with our expectations. However we think Fever-Tree’s FY19 outlook statement may be taken negatively: “At this early stage in the year, the Group is trading in line with
Board expectations”. For the past two years Fever-Tree has been more upbeat: “we have had an encouraging start”. In addition, Fever-Tree has highlighted a moderation
in UK growth rates in FY19. We think this is well understood by the market by now however it is the first time it has been put it in print. We forecast a slowdown from
52% to 15% from FY18 to FY19 in the UK. We expect growth to come increasingly from the US and Continental Europe. The wording of the outlook for each region differs
slightly. In Europe, Fever-Tree has “confidence as we move into 2019” whereas in the US it has “confidence in the medium to longer term opportunity” indicating growth
is to come through slower from the US than Europe.
Given the shares' continued high rating, any indication of a moderation in revenue growth is likely to be taken negatively by investors.

JP11:41am

(I think you just did Bryce.)

11:42 am
BE11:42am

And Jefferies.

AC21 Thanks - do you have the link?
BE11:42am

3% EPS beat (2% from better margin, 1% from lower tax) and positive tone
should provide a boost to shares today. FEVR remains one of the most attractive
growth stories in European beverages given the potential for premium mixers
internationally. However, near term we see a risk of a hiatus period as growth in the
UK core business moderates before US accelerates. Long-term prospects remain
attractive; retain Hold until further evidence of US acceleration.
F18 results - 3% EPS beat
F18 revenues £237m (cons £236m). Adj EBITDA +34% to £78.6m (Jeff £77m, cons
£77.4m) on 51.8% margin (FY17 34.5%) and EPS 53.19p (Jeff 51.47p, cons 51.97p).
DPS increased to 14.5p (Jeff 14p, cons 13.49p). Analyst meeting 8.30am (UK time).
Margins - slightly better than expected
Gross margin contraction -144bp to 51.8% after F17 53.5% (Jeff -203bp to 51.5%)
which largely reflects the impact of the UK sugar tax. EBITDA margin -116bp to 33.3%
vs F17 34.5% (Jeff -187bp to 32.6%). Co med-term guidance on gross margins c50%
with EBITDA margins c30%.
3% EPS beat - 2% from EBITDA, 1% from tax
EPS +36% to 53.19p (Jeff +31% to 51.47p, cons 51.97p) a 3.3% beat vs our forecast.
This reflects 2% beat at EBITDA and remainder from lower effective tax rate 18.26%
(Jef 19%) vs F17 19.35%.
F19 guidance - "trading in line with board expectations"
In its outlook the co states "at this early stage in the year, group is trading in-line with
Board expectations and remains excited about the size of the opportunity ahead". This
compares to F18 guidance given with F17 results "We have had an encouraging start
to 2018 and remain confident that we are increasingly well positioned to deliver further
growth across the business". We model F19 group revenue +18% with UK moderating
to +12.5% partly offset by US accelerating to +25%. We see further pressure on gross
margin (-50bp) but stable EBITDA margin. Net-net we look for F19 EPS growth +17%
to 60.04p (cons 59.6p).

BE11:42am

Likely share price reaction?
After recent weakness, we expect some relief rally with EBITDA beat and confident
tone on both Europe and USA and the future opportunity for premium mixers and
long alcoholic drinks.

BE11:50am

Any firm proposal from Sports Direct regarding an offer for the company will be given due consideration by the board. Given the timetable associated with any public offer, an offer for the company would not, in itself, address Debenhams' immediate funding requirement. Therefore, the company will continue with its plan to obtain the funding required, as outlined in Debenhams' statement of 22 March 2019.

Any proposal from Sports Direct must provide (i) an indication of the offer price, form of consideration and any other terms of such possible offer; (ii) a clear plan of how Debenhams' existing debt - which will fall due on any change of control - will be repaid; and (iii) a proposal that addresses the immediate funding requirements of the business.

In accordance with Rule 2.6(a) of the Code, Sports Direct will have until 5.00pm on 22 April 2019 to announce either a firm intention to make an offer for the Company or that it does not intend to make an offer, in which case the announcement will be treated as a statement to which Rule 2.8 of the Code applies. This deadline can be extended with the consent of the Panel in accordance with Rule 2.6(c) of the Code.

Debenhams also acknowledges that a new request to convene a shareholder meeting was received from Sports Direct on 21 March.

JP12:06pm

Here's UBS, titled "The slow-down is here".

JP12:06pm

Q2 trading still fine but downgrade to H219
Q2 organic growth remained resilient at +6.5%, with the US robust at +9.7% org
growth. Trading profit grew more moderately +4% (trading day impacts by –US12m)
to US$312m (1% below UBSE). Margins compressed by -20bps to 6.1%, with the US
compressing by -50bps to 7.0%. H219 organic growth is guided to 3-5% (H1 was
+6.5%) with end markets weakening. We think this implies the US slows to below 5%.
EBITA is guided to towards the low end of the consensus range which is US$1,585m
(cons US$1,629m/UBSE US$1,620m). This is net of US$15m M&A integration costs
(~50% to come in H2) but also incl. US$45m acquired EBITA (UBSE US$27m) this
implies a 2-3% downgrade for FY19 but on an annualised basis closer to 4-5%.

12:06 pm
JP12:07pm

US now clearly slowing down
While the US remained robust at 9.7% organic growth in Q2 and H1, it is now clearly
slowing down. We think this is not that surprising given the weaker trends in Housing
over the last few quarters, but we believe the sharpness of the moderation in growth
will surprise some. With weaker top line growth, operating leverage is guided not to
make the previous double-digit flow through in H219 but rather 6-7%. This implies
margins will compress.

JP12:07pm

Active on M&A; tax domicile back to UK
In H1 US$590m of deals were concluded with one larger deal in the US. We expect a
return to lower run rate spend going forward. Net debt was US1,885m (UBSE
US1,541m) with the difference net M&A spend. The Dutch business was sold for
US$111m (UBE was ~US$140m). Tax domicile is planned to move back to the UK from
Switzerland with effective tax rate set to go to 25-26% in FY20, in line with previous
guidance (UBSE: 25%)

JP12:07pm

and Peel Hunt:

Soundbuy Cheers all
12:07 pm
JP12:08pm

Interim results – First half results saw Ferguson post 8% growth in revenue to $10.8bn and 8% growth in operating profits to $744bn, marginally behind our estimate. The shortfall was again in the UK business. US profits advanced 8% accounting for $700m or 91% of the group total. Interim dividend has been upped by 10% to 63.1c while net debt was up at $1.89bn from $1.4bn a year ago on the back of acquisitions. Leverage was 1.1x.

JP12:09pm

Outlook & Forecasts – The business has seen a moderation in growth rates of late and as a result it now expects results to be towards the lower end of the analyst range [EBIT of c$1585m]. This implies a c2.5% cut to our estimates.

JP12:09pm

Performance & Valuation – The shares have been relatively quiet ytd with a 5% rise compared to a 12% bounce in the wider builders merchants space. 2018 saw the shares drop 11%. On current estimates the shares are trading on a PE of c13.5x for CY19. The shares have averaged c17x in the last five years and while the US economy may not grow as fast, we still expect the business to deliver robust mid single digit growth in the next few years.
